Erwin Chargaff investigated the nucleotide composition of <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. He analyzed <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from various organisms and measured the relative amounts of adenine (<math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), guanine (<math alttext="G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), cytosine (<math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), and thymine (<math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) present in the <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of each organism. Table 1 contains a selected data set of his results.

choices.label: Since the <math alttext="percent A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="percent G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> add up to approximately 50 percent in each sample, adenine and guanine molecules must pair up in a double-stranded <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

Since the <math alttext="percent A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="percent T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are approximately the same in each sample, adenine and thymine molecules must pair up in a double-stranded <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

Since the <math alttext="percent open parenthesis, A plus T, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mo>(</mo><mtext>A</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>T</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is greater than the <math alttext="percent open parenthesis, G plus C, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>G+</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in each sample, <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules must have a poly-<math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> tail at one end.

Since the <math alttext="percent C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="percent T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>%</mo><mtext>T</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> add up to approximately 50 percent in each sample, cytosine and thymine molecules must both contain a single ring.
